message.content:
<teammate-message teammate_id="team-lead" summary="Vote on "(constitutive) character" format">
The author refines the format. Instead of "constitutive character" at first occurrence, use:

**(constitutive) character (德 De)**

The parentheses around "constitutive" visually signal that the qualifier is clarifying but will drop away. Then plain "character" in running text thereafter.

Compare:
- Option A: "constitutive character (德 De)" → then "character"
- Option B (author's proposal): "(constitutive) character (德 De)" → then "character"

The difference is subtle but Option B makes the shortening feel built-in from the start — the parentheses tell the reader "this word is here to help you, but it's not part of the term."

YES or NO? Brief response.
</teammate-message>

input.content: YES. Option B is better. The parentheses around "(constitutive)" elegantly encode the shortening convention into the notation itself, so the reader immediately sees that "constitutive" is a removable qualifier rather than part of the core term. It is a cleaner signal than relying solely on a TN to explain the drop.
input.summary: YES to Option B "(constitutive) character" format

routing.summary: YES to Option B "(constitutive) character" format
